headline: CNN Tonight
subHeadline: Debates Heats Up Prior To Midterm Elections; Former President Sounds Braggadocios; Beauty From Formula Comes With A Price; Meghan Markle Claims To Be Objectified; James Corden Can Now Go Back To Balthazar. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: JAKE TAPPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: And thank you so much for joining us tonight. You can follow me on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and the TikTok at Jake Tapper. Our coverage now continues with the glorious Laura Coates and the radiant Alisyn Camerota. Hey, Laura. Hey, Alisyn.

utterances.speaker: LAURA COATES, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: You're getting better by the day. Glorious.

utterances.speaker: ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: This is never going to get old.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Not.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: This stick is never going to get --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: We were wondering if you were going to run out of superlatives, but no, you're not.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: No. Impossible. Impossible.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: The beauty of a Thesaurus.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Jocular, Jake. Fantastic. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Jocular, Jake.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That's --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Have a great night.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I need boots. Good night. Look, while we're here we're going to keep the conversation going here on CNN TONIGHT, everyone.Good evening. I'm Laura Coates.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And I'm Alisyn Camerota. With the midterms just 21 days away things are getting hot in Floridatonight in the first and only debate between Marco Rubio and Val Demings. So, we'll play you some portions.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Plus, never before heard until now, anyway, tapes of the then president talking to Bob Woodward.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: So, you're about to hear his real thoughts on Vladimir Putin and Russia and his own impeachment. And we also have brand-new audio from Trump's inner circle, meaning his son-in-law, Jared.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Remember, we know it. We never heard his voice. But remember --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And we're about to, yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: -- there was a whole thing about and what he sounds like.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: We're going to hear it again.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: We'll find out tonight.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: This is how we've been devolving this story and the story that everyone is talking about tonight as well. Hair straightening link to higher rates of uterine cancer and black women may be more affected.So, is the pressure to look a certain way now affecting our health? I mean, the idea of beauty standards and how it's judged. This story to me is really so relevant. We need to elevate it even more. I mean, the idea that something you're putting on your body in a treatment is causing cancer to the extent of even doubling for black women.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And believe me, white women get their hair straightened a lot too.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I mean, it's sobering for all of us because I guess I should have known that formaldehyde is bad for you. But I didn't know that it had such a direct link to uterine cancer.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I mean, that and just you think about all the different impacts that we're talking about. We're going to cover it more tonight and we're in depth, but I just think it's such an important story that it can't get lost in the shuffle. So, we're going to cover it here. I'm glad. We're also going to a lot talk about tonight, so kick off for our midterms any elections happening.Here with us is Brendan Buck, a former top aide to Paul Ryan and John Boehner, also CNN political commentator. Ashley Allison and chief political correspondent Dana Bash. What a panel. Glad they're all here tonight.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Fantastic guys. Great being here with you guys. So, OK. Should we play something from the Val Demings, Marco Rubio?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Let's talk about.BRENDAN BUCK, FORMER TOP AIDE TO PAUL RYAN & JOHN BOEHNER:  Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: They -- they dove right into it and they talk about abortion. So, let's talk about that.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. MARCO RUBIO (R-FL):  I'm a hundred percent pro-life because I -- not because I want to deny anyone their rights, but because I believe that innocent human life is worthy of the protection of our laws. That said, every bill I've ever sponsored on abortion, every bill I've ever voted for has exceptions. Every one of them does, because that's what can pass, and that's what the majority of people support. The extremist on abortion in this campaign is Congresswoman Demings. She supports no restrictions, no limitations of any kind. REP. VAL DEMINGS (D-FL):  Senator, how gullible do you really think Florida voters are? Number one, you have been clear that you support no exceptions, even including rape and incest. Now, as a police detective who investigated cases of rape and incest, no, Senator, I don't think it's OK for a 10-year-old girl to be raped and have to carry the seed of her rapist. No, I don't think it's OK for you to make decisions for women and girls as a senator. I think those decisions are made between the woman, her family, her daughter, and her faith. And to sit over or to stand over there and say that I support, don't support abortions up to the time of birth. It's just a lie. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, I mean, she leaned right into the whole police chops of this, but also, did you happen to catch what Rubio said? It's what can pass. I mean, for many voters, you think to yourself, I mean, it's not you have to have pie in the sky ideals, but is the standard only pursue that which can be accomplished? Is that really where we are?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And also, who do you trust? I mean, she also fact checked him --

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- down because he said, every bill I've ever voted for has acceptance, but he just co-sponsored one with Senator -- the one with Senator Graham. It doesn't make an exception for rape or incest. And she called that out. I mean, I'm not sure what he's, I guess he's trying to thread the needle and make people think that it has more exceptions than it does.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: She even called the voters how gullible do you think they are --

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: -- based on that point.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right. And also, fact check, reality check. That's not going to pass now. Probably not in the near future because even if Republicans do take the Senate, it will be by a seat, a couple of seats, not the 60 votes needed to break a filibuster. And that's what would be needed.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But the Graham bill --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But, yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But the Graham bill does have exceptions.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But doesn't have it for rape and incest.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I believe it does.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I believe it does.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: There are some --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I believe it does.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: So that I stand corrected. I'm going to check that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I believe it does. But I think what is, what was really interesting about Marco Rubio's answer, yes, it was very practical but it was, he was in one sentence able to say, this is what I believe, like a shout out to the most conservative voters on this issue.I am 100 percent pro-life. And yet, also, sort of say, look, I am -- I've been in the Senate and I know what it takes, and I know what the majority of people want which is exceptions, which is exceptions for abortion.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I will now do a dramatic reading from our CNN right.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Senator Rubio co-sponsored a Senate bill introduced by South Carolina Senator Lindsey Graham that would ban abortion in every state at 15 weeks without exceptions for rape and incest.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK, so there you go.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That was a dramatic read.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That was a dramatic read. And to be quite honest, I didn't memorize the ins and outs of that because this was a very deliberate political ploy by Senator Graham, and I guess Senator Rubio in order to get Republicans on record with something that they support because they were getting so --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: And frankly, a very selfish move --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- (Inaudible) by Democrats.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: -- by Senator Graham. Because he wanted to score points, I think like Rubio was doing there with the base with Evangelicals saying, here -- here's what I'm for.I think what Marco Rubio was trying to do there was pushes back a little bit on Democrats. And this is some of the frustration that Republicans have been having. There's a lot of questions about where's your line? Is it 15 weeks? Is it 12 weeks? Is it -- is never. A lot of Republicans go, well, what's the Democrats line? Where -- at what point do you want to draw the line on what an abortion OK? And I think it's a very fair question and Democrats don't get asked it a lot. And I think he was trying to push it back on her. She did a very good job of not taking that bait. Pushing back on him. I will say any conversation about abortion right now is a win for Val Demings. This is not a topic that Republicans want to be talking about. I think the topics that were discussed in this debate, whether it was guns, abortion, the elections all benefit heard. Not as much conversation in this debate about the election or about the economy, which is what Marco Rubio wants to be covering.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And that's part of the issue, right, when Lindsey Graham put that into the universe on the day that President Biden was signing the Inflation Reduction Act, which many Republicans thought could be an easy win to try to undermine it in some way and say, the title doesn't sound like it's going to be a short-term win in these issues. And he came out with this very thing.But I still go back to the point in many respects of and I think it's, you know, a difficult thing. On the one hand, you are not taken seriously as a politician, right? Unless you know you can actually get what your platform you're saying passed. So, he is talking about what he can do, but still, for voters, for many of whom are younger voters, first time voters, they do want the hope of getting things done outside of the institution in Washington.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: They don't want a national abortion ban though. And that is actually what the Graham bill is, and it's contradictory to what Republicans are saying. They said the Dobbs decision was to take the decision back to the states. And then you have Lindsey Graham introducing something that would do a blanket abortion ban, and that's not what the average American wants. They do want exceptions.I do hear your point about what are Democrats rules. I think the line for them is it's a woman's choice and let it be between her and her doctor.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: I mean, polling will show there is a big swath in the middle of the country that believes there should be -- they should always be able to have an abortion in certain circumstances. But there are -- should be limits on at what point.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: And that's a, that's a big conversation and a big, big group people to have. What Republicans, to your point, what Republicans have in my mind screwed up is we've always said we want to be the reasonable ones. Let states have some reasonable restrictions.And when we just like, in states where you're going to six weeks or zero weeks or you're having an act, it's contradictory to what we've been saying for years and years and years about why we -- people should trust us.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Think about it. I mean, one way to have solve this, right, Roe v. Wade did have those limitations in part, right?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Viability.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: They had trimester framework, the viability framework, essentially a fetus that could be viable outside the womb with that medical intervention essentially was going to be that that threshold.[22:10:00] Which is one of the reasons that Republicans don't want to be talking about the issue because there was the decision that could have had that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. And I think what you said about questioning Democrats on what their threshold is, whether or not they want any, any legal limits at all is something that I ask --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- because it is important. Because this is now a state's issue. So, when you're talking to people who are running for governor, more governor, I think than in Congress because it's probably less likely now that you're going to get a national piece of legislation that for at least the short term, it's probably going to be a state's issue. That -- that matters.It's a very, very big question. And for the Democrats who don't want any restrictions and they say it should exclusively be a decision between a woman and her doctor, they are a bit out of step with the way polling shows.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Before we go, I want to play something else that Senator Lindsey Graham said today. And this was with Herschel Walker, because he actually spelled out what he really likes about Herschel Walker, which I think is interesting for everybody to hear. Here it is.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC):  So being from South Carolina, I'm begging you to elect Herschel for the benefit of the people of my state. We're all in this together in Washington, right? If we had one more senator in Washington in the Republican column, I would be the budget chairman, not Bernie Sanders. (APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: GRAHAM
utterances.sentences: That is a good trade, Herschel. Trust me.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That's what he likes about Herschel Walker. Power.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But that's --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: He can get a promotion.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: But that's what they're all doing here.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's a trade-off here. I mean, you kind of, people have been wondering what is.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: You shouldn't be -- you shouldn't be surprised by this. ALLISON

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: In other words --

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: That is the frame they want. That this seat decides who controls the Senate.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's not just about him.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: That's not -- that's not about the budget chair, that's about control. The Mitch McConnell being a majority, minority.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That (Inaudible) said, but I just like that Lindsey Graham said, and I would get a promotion.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Well, that's what they're trying to say. This is not about Herschel Walker. Forget Herschel Walker.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: This is the Republican and that's --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Because they know he's a disaster.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: And that's generally what Republicans are saying in the state. And he had a debate last Friday where he actually did a good job presenting himself as generic Republican. Where there are some weird moments where he is holding up a badge. Absolutely.But he did a very good job of framing this as Raphael Warnock, the Democrat is going to vote with Joe Biden. I'm the Republican, I'm going to be a check on him.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How --

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: That's as simple as it can be.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How many times did your bosses and the Republican leadership pre-Trump distance themselves from people with scandals like Herschel Walker has? A lot, right? Well, --

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: The exact same scandal.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The exact same scandal. Exactly. I know Trent Franks, as you're talking about.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: And Tim Murphy and the several other folks.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And others, OK.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's not happening now for lots of reasons. Trump changed the game in some ways, but it's also because they have their eyes on the majority, and if they throw Herschel Walker under the bus, then it's pretty much, forgive me, game over for the notion of taking back the majority for Republicans.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: This was a pivot, right? The idea of telling people why him in spite of. I mean, now we're talking about the in spite of candidacy, which is a whole new threshold. We're in politics right now. Everyone.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you, guys very much. Dana, thank you.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: We're good nighting you. Everybody else, you're not going anywhere. Stick around.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Next we have exclusive audio tapes of Bob Woodward's interviews with President Trump, including what Trump says about the letters from Kim Jong-un. Are those letters part of all those classified documents that Trump took home? We'll find out.(BEGIN VOICE CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, FORMER PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Nobody else has them, but I want you to treat them with respect. I haven't.

utterances.speaker: BOB WOODWARD, AUTHOR, RAGE
utterances.sentences: I understand. I understand.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Now to a CNN exclusive legendary journalist Bob Woodward is releasing an audiobook of 20 interviews he conducted with then President Donald Trump from 2016 to 2020. The book comes out next week.But CNN special correspondent Jamie Gangel has clips from those tapes for us tonight. Also, back with us we have Brendan Buck and Ashley Allison. Well, this is a gold mine.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Jamie, these -- these clips are incredible. What jumped out at you.

utterances.speaker: JAMIE GANGEL, CNN SPECIAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Eight hours. And it's not just Donald Trump. You hear the people around him as well. But I'm going to start with something that really, I think shows Donald Trump. It will not surprise you. It is unvarnished, it is profane. That means he swears a lot, and he attacks people of people who don't like him, and he boasts a lot about himself.But what I thought was revealing is how much he wants to impress Bob Woodward. You just hear it over and over and at times he thinks he can impress him by telling him classified information. Here we go. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I have built a weapon system that nobody's ever had in this country before. We have stuff that you haven't even seen or heard about. We have stuff that Putin and XI have never heard about before.Getting along with Russia is a good thing and a bad thing, all right? Especially because they have 1,332 nuclear fucking warheads. It's funny. The relationships I have, the tougher and meaner they are, the better I get along with them. You'll explain that to me someday. OK. But maybe it's not a bad thing. The easy ones are the ones I maybe don't like as much or don't get along with as much. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: So just to clarify, Woodward was never able to verify whether this system exists, but he uses it as an example. And there are many throughout the audiobooks of how Trump's national security advisors, their heads are exploding because Trump is just repeatedly so cavalier, dangerous, reckless, careless, with classified information.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: He was being taped.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I know he's being taped.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's the mindboggling --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: He know he's being taped.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: A hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's the mindboggling part of this. The idea that speaking about Cavallari and the way he does, but he also goes on to talk about there's some chest beating about how tough he is, which we've heard oftentimes before, but he digs in again here in a way that was just odd.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Look, this is classic Donald Trump. I think if you go through the transcript from the audiobook and you put the word tough in, it's every graph --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: -- that comes up or cool. He's very cool. He's very tough. And one of the things we saw was he also shared with Woodward those Kim Jong-un, "the love letters." Those are classified. They may not be the most top-secret thing in the world, but he's not supposed to be sharing them with a journalist.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: In fact, these are part of the reason he's under investigation, these letters, right?

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: So certainly, these were one of the things that he wouldn't return. And obviously, everybody knew about them --

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Right?

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: -- because it was public. Eventually after a year, the National Archives, they got those back as part of the 15 boxes that Trump sent back in January. But they had to pry it away from, from him.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Let's listen to the audio clip of him revealing these to this classified information to Bob Woodward.(BEGIN VOICE CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Nobody else has them, but I want you to treat them with respect. I haven't -- with anybody.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: I understand. I understand.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: And don't say I gave them to you. OK?

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: But I think it's OK. Normally I wouldn't have given, I wasn't going to give him to Bob, you know?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: What, do you make a photostat of them or something? WOODWARD

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: Yes.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: So, the whole photostat thing, you know, goes back to, you guys are too young, but I remember the mimeograph in high school. I think we're talking about the same time, but listen to what Trump says.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Usually I don't do this, but here you go.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Right. But here it is, and don't tell anyone I gave them to you.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I mean, again, he knows he's being taped. Right?

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: A hundred percent.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: During this.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: It's hard not to hear him. Look, Bob Woodward is a legend, right? And Donald Trump loves famous people. It's very hard to listen to that and not think he's just really trying to impress Bob Woodward.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I hear that.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Because he knows Bob Woodward is famous.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: And to your point --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But why is he a legend for essentially undermining a President?

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's the shocking part.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: Exactly. But he -- but he likes the fact that someone is going to write a book about him. And if anybody, if you've had the pleasure of hearing Donald Trump privately, it's hard not to be astonished by the way that he zigs and he zags and he meanders and has parentheticals and just nonquitters, and he jumps all over the place.But he really just wants to impress people. Ultimately, that's what it is. He wants to impress you. He wants to charm you, and I think that's what he's doing here.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: He also is telling him, treat it with respect. How about you treat it with respect? They're classified documents like, some consistency here. And he does want to impress Woodward. But he also, I feel that there's this sense that he is above it all and that I can give it to you because I'm the king of the castle, and I am like the ruler of the land and the rules don't apply to me.And that is, so many people caught him a narcissist. But that is what, like his behavior is narcissistic behavior.

utterances.speaker: BUCK
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. Why do we think he has it at Mar-a-Lago? Because he wants to show his visitors the things that he has.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the thing, which is if he showed it to Bob Woodward, is that the only person that he showed the classified stuff to? We don't know, but it seems hard to believe.Laura was pointing out earlier that we went a long time without ever hearing Jared Kushner's voice.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And people didn't know, you know, speculated there were, I think, comedic bits about what it was actually like.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Darth Vader, or Gilbert Gottfried, we didn't know.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: So -- Gottfried. So here, here it is. Should we play this portion?

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Yes. Can I just set it up by telling you that what's happened before this is that Donald Trump has put Jared on the phone with Woodward so that Jared will arrange for Woodward to have interviews with other people in the White House.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK. Got it. Let's listen.(BEGIN VOICE CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JARED KUSHNER, FORMER SENIOR ADVISOR TO THE PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Hello.

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: Jared. Bob Woodward. How are.

utterances.speaker: KUSHNER
utterances.sentences: Good. How are you?

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: Did you hear what he said that I'm going to come see you. We've got a date scheduled; I think next week. And then, you --

utterances.speaker: KUSHNER
utterances.sentences: Perfect.

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: -- can help me with some of these other people I want to talk to. Is that --

utterances.speaker: KUSHNER
utterances.sentences: Perfect. Well, what I'll do is I'll make a list of other people. What I heard from the president is basically that I now work for you. So, I will make myself available, around that schedule. And I will make sure I get you a good list. I'll come up with my list, and if you come with your list of wants. I will work to try to make it all happen.

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: I want you to know I have no illusions that you work for me. I know you worked for Ivanka, right?

utterances.speaker: KUSHNER
utterances.sentences: OK. Fine. You get it. You get it. That's probably why you're Bob Woodward.

utterances.speaker: WOODWARD
utterances.sentences: I get it.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That's a funny exchange.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: He is Bob Woodward, though. I mean, the idea of, I guess I'm still going back this point. I'm always a little bit tickled by just how open and accommodating people are with --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: He hypnotizes people.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: -- with journalists who clearly are going to be writing a story that's going to be hopefully objective and not have you smelling like roses.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: So a couple of things that I've learned about Bob Woodward over the years, he doesn't give up. He will come and knock on your door at 10 o'clock at night. He also talks to so many people that when he shows up, he has the receipts even before he starts. He says, well, you said this then and this, and so people really want to talk to him to make sure they get their side of the story.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I feel for Jared in that exchange because he doesn't know who his boss is anymore. You know, I got the impression that President Trump is like, today you work for the secretary of state. Today, you work for Bob Woodward. Today you work for Ivanka, and he's just long suffering, Jared, having to do whatever the president says. That was my impression from listening to that.This is great, Jamie. Really, it really incredible to hear this. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: It's -- it's Bob Woodward's work. I'm just lucky enough to have listened to it first.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I'll tell you what, if Bob Woodward is knocking on someone's door at 10 o'clock, he's not watching us. So, I'm -- it's already a problem.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes, Bob.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: To midnight.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: I think -- I think he's watching us.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: OK, fine. He's watching. There you go. I'm not saying.

utterances.speaker: GANGEL
utterances.sentences: Say hello.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Well, there's a new study by the National Institute of Health that is raising a lot of concern around the use of chemical hair straightening products, particularly among black women. If you didn't notice from your screen, you were looking at one.The study followed more than 33,000 women ages 35 to 74 in the United States who have used hair dyes, straighteners, relaxers, or pressing products for an average of over 10 years. About 60 percent of participants identified as black women. Now, over that time 378 women were diagnosed with uterine cancer. Here with this now CNN political analyst, Laura Barron-Lopez, political commentator, Ashley Allison and senior political analyst, Kirsten Powers. You know, this is a topic that is very near and dear to my heart. I am natural. I no longer straighten my hair chemically, but there was a time that I did. And the idea that so many people I know did so at an early age, did so for a very long time, and now might have the risk of uterine cancer. And it's linked in many ways, some do so to try to conform certain beauty standards in our world, let alone the industry and beyond. And I'm resentful of the fact that this is even occurring. And we were talking about this in makeup, you and I, about when did you have your first relaxer and when did you get it? When did you decide not to do it any longer? And it's a real conversation that black women are always having.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Yes, black women hair, it's a sacred topic. It's a part of our culture. And I thank my mom for protecting my hair and not letting me get a relaxer until I was a teenager because it literally changes the chemical makeup of your hair to make it irreversible, to go back to its natural state.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: You have to cut it off.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: You have to cut it off and start all over again. And one of the reasons that so many black women, and there's no judgment on how people wear your hair, I think everyone has their choice to how they want to appear. But a lot of black women do straighten their hair because for so long, that was the quote, unquote, "mainstream image of beauty."We are now in this renaissance of owning who we are and being proud and really leaning into black is beautiful like in the 60s and wearing natural hair, and making sure that corporate America and that on television we can wear our hair in natural ways because it's a part of who we are. It's a part of our culture.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. And by the way, I mean, white women get pressured to straighten their hair too. I mean, because there is a beauty standard for black women and white women to have straight, silky hair.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Or to color it. CAMEROTA

utterances.speaker: KIRSTEN POWERS, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST
utterances.sentences: I mean, when your skin, you know, your skin is kind of on fire.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: You're sitting there and you're like --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Literally.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: -- could this possibly be bad? I mean, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Could this be bad? There's fumes like, and you're holding like --

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- a towel over your face. And obviously if somebody had said, if I had known, if there had been disclosure it's linked to uterine cancer, I would never have done it. But for the sake of this sort of universal beauty, I was doing it.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: But also, there's the, even if it wasn't bad for you, why should anybody have to do this? Why should women have to spend the money, the time have to reject what they look like? Your hair is amazing. Right? I mean, it's insane that there was actually a time where you would not be able to have the job that you have if you didn't conform to whatever the idea was of basically a bunch of men.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But it has changed. You all of you saying that.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.BARRON-LOPEZ:  Yes. It has changed.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It has changed. You know, and for, I have a little girl and so in my hair I say is natural. I blow dry it, I flat iron it. I mean, you know, I was once in the salon to color it, but I was next to you. I don't want to, I know. But for my daughter, I intentionally wear my hair naturally around my daughter.Because I want her to understand that this is what beauty looks like and that it's also what she looks like and her hair looks like mine when it's natural. And this is what I have to constantly think about. You always say things like representation matters. You got to see yourself on television. See yourself in books. See yourself in theater. See yourself in politics. And there's few instances where I think people are really seeing themselves and to think, and we we're sitting here about five minutes ago trying to figure out name a woman on television with gray hair.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Right.BARRON-LOPEZ:  Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: We can't come up with one.BARRON-LOPEZ:  No.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It's absurd.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, no, because I was saying like I actually would like to go gray. Maybe I will go gray now.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: My gosh.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: You know.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: You're ushing me to (Inaudible) .

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Because, no, because I -- because I resent it because there are men here who have gray hair and nobody has a problem with it. Right? No one has ever --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: It means wisdom for them.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. They're established and all these other things. And so, for a woman, it's somehow, there's a reason that women haven't done it is because we think we're going to get punished for it. And so, we spend, like I said, I go back to the money and the time that women spend, that men don't have to spend, just maintaining ourselves so that we're acceptable to society. Just to be acceptable. It's not even to be on a different, you know, level or something.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: I think the thing that is, so I was in the gym and my friend said, my gosh, have you seen this? And I think the thing that's so destruct -- disturbing is that what testing, what other things are we using on our body?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: That they're pushing down our throats and we have no idea the impact in the long term.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes. ALLISONstraighten there. But the way relaxers, I mean, and just for me, perm, there's like a whole TikTok trend. Like where are the just for me perm girls at 20 years from now, because it was shoved down, the marketing was pushed down on long -- little black girls, that if you didn't have silky straight hair with the little bow, you were not pretty, and that nobody would want you, nobody would love you.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Let me tell you something. For our conversations there should be no judgment. Wear your hair how you want to wear it. I like to wear my hair the way I like to wear my hair. I hope you all do as well. But if you're doing it because someone tells you that, that is how you are supposed to look. Call me. You guys write a conversation to happen and that's, well, that's just for me.Thank you very much. See, I did there.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: That goes around the world.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Well, I want you to know about and what you think about this study as well and the pressure society puts on black and Latina women and really women more broadly about beauty standards. That and anything else you want to say to Alisyn and me within reason.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Meghan Markle talks about being objectified. In the newest episode of her podcast, Archetypes. Markle described her experience as a so-called briefcase girl on the game show Deal or No Deal back in 2000.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: MEGHAN, DUCHESS OF SUSSEX
utterances.sentences: I mean, you have to imagine, just to paint the picture for you, that before the tapings of the show, all the girls, we would line up and there were different stations for having your lashes put on, or your extensions put in, or the padding in your bra. We were even given spray tan vouchers each week.Because there was a very cookie cutter idea of precisely what we should look like. It was solely about beauty and not necessarily about brains. And when I look back at that time, I will never, I'll never forget this one detail, because moments before we'd get on stage, there was a woman who ran the show and she would be there back stage. And I can still hear her. She couldn't properly pronounce my last name at the time, and I knew who she was talking to because she would go, Mark-el, suck it in. Mark-el, suck it in. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Was paid.BARRON-LOPEZ:  -- presumably knew what she was entering when she took the job. It doesn't mean that she should have to deal with someone who was telling her to suck it in. I think that it's refreshing that Meghan Markle talks about these things, even though that was part of that job's M.O. and that job -- that job description. And I think it, her talking about it potentially raises questions as to whether or not do we need models next to these suitcases? I mean, do we need women to standing next to all these suitcases. Do we really need Vanna White in all -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know.BARRON-LOPEZ:  All this lengthy dresses.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I love Wheel of Fortune.BARRON-LOPEZ:  You know, sorry, not Wheel of Fortune. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: That's fair.BARRON-LOPEZ:  Some of this, this is a model, the other term for a model because it works.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but Alisyn, don't -- I think the bigger problem is that if you're Meghan Markle starting out how many years ago this was, this was a while ago. These are the options for women and men have different options, and then that's what the point is. The point is she probably didn't really have a choice. She did have to do this. It doesn't make it any less humiliating that she was doing it well.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: She didn't have to take that job.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: And if you don't -- well, I don't, I don't think that's fair. I actually think that's kind of like blaming the victim. The fact that a woman, the fact that a woman doesn't have a lot of options in Hollywood except to have to play bimbos, you know, is not Meghan Mark's fault. It's Hollywood's fault.And so, you know, I don't know that she had a lot of options to break in. And then that's the problem is that women are -- this is what women -- the options that women are given and there's all these other options for men. And we know for a long time it's starting to change because we're having more women directors and things like that, especially because of streaming. But at the time she was breaking into the business, I don't think there were a lot of options. And I think that this just speaks badly to the people who were in control.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: I agree. I also think is what is the standard of beauty? Do you have to be a size four --BARRON-LOPEZ:  Yes.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: -- with straight hair and have large breasts and all of the things that people say like this is what the Barbie image of what you need to look like, spray tan for a certain complexion, but not too dark of a complexion.And it does go to, like, the gang would've still existed without the women next to the suitcase. Like the deal was in the case, not the women.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I guess. But I don't know if anybody is ever gone broke putting beautiful women on TV. I mean.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Well, that's the point though. I mean, and part of it, and I think it's, it's kind of like I've had this conversation and no disrespect to cheerleaders. I fully support everyone doing what they want to do. But are you that much more interested in the game by the presence of it?So, I'm going to argue the Halftime Show. I mean, I'm not just discriminating against that notion of it. But I look at it as more of a reflection of what Hollywood requires and the idea of saying, look, here's what we -- here's what we know is going to feed the audience. Here's what we know is going to be something that is enticing to people. And she was also speaking to Paris Hilton as part of this conversation who has been very vocal in years since her original sort of debut as a socialite to talk about how it was a famed put-on sort of, dits.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And that served her well to be thought of as Coquettish and meek and not fully in the room.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: The bimbo.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And you know, in reality there was a lot more going on. And I think that does speak about why it would be, that's a safe space for people to go, she's non-threatening. There's nothing there or there. And we are by the way, five-year anniversary from the Me Too movement. These combinations have been happening over and over again.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But I mean, I guess I would just say about Paris Hilton, she was playing a role and Meghan Markle is playing a role and she made it her brand. I mean, Paris Hilton made that her brand.Now of course, we can talk about who was forcing her to make it that brand, and did she have to make it the brand. But she rode that brand for years. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: But I don't think anybody was even forced to do anything. I just think things happen. I -- you have to remember how young she was, and that you get into these situations and I'll just speak about it getting into television and maybe you could as well. You come into --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I know that this is ringing truth for you.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: It's tough.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. ALLISONBut I think the point though of this is that where does it stop? Yes. Meghan was holding a briefcase on a game show and Paris was playing a reality star. One of the first to introduce, but we also know it carries over in other sectors. It carries over in television. It carries over in politics. Candidates, what do they look like? What are they wearing?

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: They dissect the vice president's wardrobe --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: Every day.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ALLISON
utterances.sentences: How she wears her hair. She takes how long in makeup? Well, if she came out without looking professional, what would you call her then? Michelle Obama looked like this. You know, name --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Republican women too. Get it, by the way.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Everyone.BARRON-LOPEZ:  The one thing I'll say is, whether or not she put herself into that position with the Deal or No Deal job, that I think the fact that she's talking about this makes all women, you know, and hopefully men realize when they're treating women in this way in their places. Because I've been objectified by members of Congress, you know, multiple times. And it's very difficult to come forward and talk about that. And it happens, you know, somewhat to women on a regular basis. And I think that if they see, you know, conversations like this that we're covering, that hopefully men start to realize and women who do it as well, because that was a woman that did it to Meghan Markle, that that's not acceptable to this. It shouldn't be done anymore.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry, I don't want to leave this point though. When that has happened to you in the course of your profession as a journalist, that congressmen are doing this and how do you react in those moments?BARRON-LOPEZ:  I think early on when I was younger, I didn't totally know how to act.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Yes.BARRON-LOPEZ:  When it happened in more recent years, I confronted the member with others around me, you know, right outside the floor.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: There you go.BARRON-LOPEZ:  So, and I said that they needed to stop.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: And did they?BARRON-LOPEZ:  Yes, they did. They have since.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: But there was a time if you did that, you would lose your job. Right?BARRON-LOPEZ:  That's right.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Right. There's a -- and that's what Meghan Markle, I think is talking about. Is that if she had pushed back against that, she would've lost her job. And so, it's, it's like you have to just realize. And then I do think what happens, and I think Alisyn, I keep looking at you because I know we've gone through this through our career.As you get older and you mature and society changes and the standards change and you start looking back to going, why didn't I say something?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Well, yes. I mean --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Why didn't I do something, you know?

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: And to Laura's point, the Me Too movement I do think changed a lot of things --

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: -- and particularly the national conversation and the way we all think about those things. And for that, I think we're all grateful.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Thank you for sharing, Laura.BARRON-LOPEZ:  Yes.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: POWERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Late night host James Corden temporarily banned from New York City Hotspot Balthazar. The restaurant's owner, Keith McNally, is alleging verbal abuse by Corden against the staff. McNally calling Corden a quote, "tiny cretin of a man," and quote, "the most abusive customer in Balthazar's history."

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: This makes me very sad because I think that James Corden is so appealing and he's so funny, and he's so talented, and it's a bummer that he's a jerk. But he has now apologized profusely, we're told. The ban has been revoked, thank goodness. McNally, Balthazar's owner says tonight in a self-deprecating statement, quote, "anyone magnanimous enough to apologize to a deadbeat lay about like me does not deserve to be banned from anywhere, especially Balthazar." CNN has reached out to Corden for comment. We haven't heard back yet.But this is -- this is -- there's a -- there's a lesson here. Don't ever be rude to the wait staff. Don't ever be rude to the waiters. I mean, what it --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: Or to anyone.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK. That -- that's, that's a more universal. That's a good(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: That's the lesson. That's the lesson.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: But particularly, you just are a jerk. If you're rude to the waiters and waitresses, it's just like you have a huge jerk sign. And by the way, the things he was doing in June, Corden demanded that a round of drinks come this second, and that his previous drinks be combed because he had found a hair in his food. That is gross. And he --

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: But the food, not the drinks.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. And also, did he really, I mean, I don't know. Anyway, he was extremely nasty to the manager. He also on another occasion that month, came into the restaurant with his wife for brunch and said to the server that there was a tiny bit of egg yolk in her egg white omelet. That's jerky.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I got to tell you. I mean, I, as somebody who is awfully new to being sometimes recognizable to people. I have spent a lot of my time being a bit invisible, and I can tell you I love it because I know who people really are and how you treated people that I've watched and I'm kind of like, I see you . And I think when it comes to, I've been a waitress.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Me too.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I've had all sorts of odd jobs and I can tell you about a per -- if the person treats people because they have this perceived sense of superiority.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I don't care what kind of schmoozing you can do; you'll always be seen. So maybe that's what happened here. I've also never been to Balthazar, though.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: I'll take you there. It's great. Fantastic. Fantastic.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: If there's a hair in my food, do I get to get a free meal or are you buying? Never mind she's buying. That's fine. I'll go.

utterances.speaker: CAMEROTA
utterances.sentences: OK. We want to know what you think about James Corden's -- I mean, is he a jerk or is he, did he just have a bad month. OK. Let us know about that.

utterances.speaker: COATES
utterances.sentences: I think I know how you feel.
